verse_translation.debroy_trans: Janamejaya asked, "Oppressed by fear of Duryodhana, how did my great grandfathers live in disguise in the city of Virata?"
Vaishampayana said,

verse_data: तथा तु स वराँल्लब्ध्वा धर्माद्धर्मभृतां वरः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Having obtained boons from Dharma in that fashion, the one who was foremost among upholders of dharma returned to the hermitage and told the brahmanas everything that had happened.
Having recounted everything to the brahmanas, Yudhishthira returned the kindling to the brahmana.
O descendant of the Bharata lineage! Then Dharma's son, the great-minded King Yudhishthira, called all his younger brothers and spoke to them in this way.
"Dislodged from our kingdom, we have lived for twelve years and the thirteenth has arrived now. We will have to live through a difficult period.

verse_data: स साधु कौन्तेय इतो वासमर्जुन रोचय

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O Kounteya Arjuna! Therefore, think of a desirable place where all of us may dwell, without being detected by our enemies."
Arjuna replied,
"O lord of men! O bull among the Bharata lineage! Because of the boon that has been given to us by Dharma, we can roam undetected by men.

verse_data: किं तु वासाय राष्ट्राणि कीर्तयिष्यामि कानिचित्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I will recount the kingdoms where we may dwell. Some of them are beautiful and secluded. Which of these seems attractive to you?

verse_data: सन्ति रम्या जनपदा बह्वन्नाः परितः कुरून्
दशार्णा नवराष्ट्रं च मल्लाः शाल्वा युगंधराः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Around the kingdom of the Kurus, there are many beautiful countries with an abundance of food—Panchala, Chedi, Matsya, Shurasena, Patachchara, Dasharna, Navarashtra, Malla, Shalva and Yugandhara.
O king! Which among these seems to you to be an attractive place to live in? O Indra among kings! Where will we dwell for a year?"
Yudhishthira said,
"O mighty-armed one! It will indeed be as the illustrious lord of all beings has said. It cannot be otherwise.

verse_data: अवश्यं त्वेव वासार्थं रमणीयं शिवं सुखम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: We must certainly dwell in a place that is beautiful, auspicious and pleasant, where all of us can live without any fear. Let us consult among ourselves.
The powerful Matsya Virata will protect the Pandavas. He is aged, generous, with a great deal of riches and conducts himself in accordance with dharma.
O son! O descendant of the Bharata lineage! Let us happily spend a year in the city of Virata. We will perform tasks for him there.

verse_data: यानि यानि च कर्माणि तस्य शक्ष्यामहे वयम्
कर्तुं यो यत्स तत्कर्म ब्रवीतु कुरुनन्दनाः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O descendants of the Kuru lineage! Let each one of us describe the tasks that he will perform, the kind of duties that we will undertake for him."
Arjuna replied,

verse_data: नरदेव कथं कर्म राष्ट्रे तस्य करिष्यसि

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O god among men! O virtuous one! What duty will you undertake in the kingdom of King Virata? What appeals to you?
You are gentle, generous, modest and devoted to dharma. Truth is your valour. O king! O Pandava! Confronted by this calamity, what will you do?

verse_data: स इमामापदं प्राप्य कथं घोरां तरिष्यसि

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O king! You are not familiar with the hardships faced by ordinary people. How will you pass through this calamity that has come over you?"
Yudhishthira said,
"O descendants of the Kuru lineage! Listen to the duties that I will undertake. When I arrive before King Virata, bull among men,

verse_data: कङ्को नाम द्विजो भूत्वा मताक्षः प्रियदेविता

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I will become a member of that great-souled king's assembly. I will pose as a brahmana named Kanka, skilled in dice and fond of gambling.
I will use beautiful dice made out of lapis lazuli, gold, ivory and lustrous fruit, with black and red dots.
If asked, I will tell the king that in earlier times I used to be Yudhishthira's friend, as dear to him as life itself.

verse_data: वृकोदर विराटे त्वं रंस्यसे केन कर्मणा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I have now told you how I wish to spend my time. O Vrikodara! What task will you perform in Virata?"
Bhima said,
"I think I will present myself before King Virata as a  superintendent of the kitchen and give my name as Ballava.
Since I possess culinary skills, I will cook him dishes. I will surpass all the skilled chefs who have cooked dishes for him earlier and thus generate affection in his mind.

verse_data: तत्प्रेक्ष्य विपुलं कर्म राजा प्रीतो भविष्यति

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I will fetch large loads of wood for him. The king will be pleased on witnessing my great deeds.

verse_data: द्विपा वा बलिनो राजन्वृषभा वा महाबलाः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O king! If there are powerful elephants, or immensely strong bulls, that need to be overpowered by me, I will pacify them too.
If there are warriors who need to be fought in the assembly, I will vanquish them also and increase his affection towards me.
But I will never slay any of those fighters. I will bring them down so that they do not perish.
If asked, I will say that I was cook, cattle-tender, chef and wrestler to Yudhishthira.
O lord of the earth! I will act so as to protect myself on my own. I promise that I will carry myself in this way."
Yudhishthira said,
"He is foremost among men. In a desire to burn down Khandava, he was the one before whom Agni appeared in the disguise of a brahmana in earlier times. He was accompanied by Dasharha then.

verse_data: सोऽयं किं कर्म कौन्तेयः करिष्यति धनंजयः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: He is immensely strong and mighty-armed. He is the invincible descendant of the Kuru lineage. What duty will Kounteya Dhananjaya undertake?

verse_data: श्रेष्ठः प्रतियुधां नाम सोऽर्जुनः किं करिष्यति

verse_translation.debroy_trans: He confronted the conflagration and satisfied the fire. Ascended on a single chariot, he vanquished Indra and killed the serpents and the rakshasas. He is supreme among warriors. What will Arjuna do?

verse_data: सूर्यः प्रतपतां श्रेष्ठो द्विपदां ब्राह्मणो वरः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: The sun is foremost among those that heat. The brahmana is supreme among bipeds, a poisonous one among snakes. Agni is supreme among those with energy.

verse_data: आयुधानां वरो वज्रः ककुद्मी च गवां वरः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: The vajra is supreme among weapons. A bull with a hump is supreme among cattle. The ocean is foremost among stores of water. Parjanya is supreme among those who shower down.

verse_data: पुत्रः प्रियाणामधिको भार्या च सुहृदां वरा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Dhritarashtra is supreme among nagas and Airavata among elephants. The son is supreme among those who are loved and the wife among well-wishers.
O Vrikodara! Just as there is a foremost among each specific category, this young Gudakesha is foremost among all archers.
O descendant of the Bharata lineage! He is not inferior to Indra or Vasudeva. He is the wielder of the bow Gandiva and has white horses.
What will Bibhatsu do? He lived for five years in the abode of the one with a thousand eyes. In a form that was as radiant as that of the gods, he obtained divine weapons.

verse_data: दक्षिणे चैव सव्ये च गवामिव वहः कृतः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I think that he is the twelfth Rudra and the thirteenth Aditya. His arms are smooth and long. His skin is tough, both on the right and the left, from drawing the string of the bow and marked like bulls that bear loads.
The armed Arjuna is supreme, like Himalaya among the mountains, the ocean among stores of water, Shakra among the thirty gods,
Agni among the Vasus, the tiger among animals and Garuda among winged ones. What will he do?"
Arjuna replied,

verse_data: ज्याघातौ हि महान्तौ मे संवर्तुं नृप दुष्करौ

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O lord of the earth! I promise that I will undertake the duties of a eunuch. O king! It is difficult to conceal these great marks that the string of the bow has left.
I will wear earrings as radiant as the fire on my ears. O king! I will wear a braid on my head and name myself Brihannada.
I will repeatedly recount stories and observe the characteristics of a woman. I will please the king and the others who live in the inner quarters

verse_data: गीतं नृत्तं विचित्रं च वादित्रं विविधं तथा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: through different forms of singing and dancing and the playing of varied kinds of music. O king! I will teach the women in Virata's abode these arts.
I will recount the many deeds, fruits and conducts of people. O Kounteya! I will disguise myself in this way.

verse_data: उषितास्मीति वक्ष्यामि पृष्टो राज्ञा च भारत

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O descendant of the Bharata lineage! If I am asked by the king, I will say that I was Droupadi's attendant in Yudhishthira's house.

verse_data: एतेन विधिना छन्नः कृतकेन यथा नलः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O Indra among kings! In this way, I will pleasantly spend my time in Virata's abode, disguising myself through deceit, just as Nala had done."
Yudhishthira asked,

verse_data: किं त्वं नकुल कुर्वाणस्तत्र तात चरिष्यसि

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O Nakula! O son! You are delicate, brave, handsome and used to pleasure. What will you do and how will you act?"
Nakula replied,
"I will become a keeper of horses for King Virata. I find pleasure in that kind of work and will give myself the name of Granthika.

verse_data: प्रियाश्च सततं मेऽश्वाः कुरुराज यथा तव

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I am skilled in training horses and also in treating horses. O king of the Kuru lineage! I have always loved horses, just as much as you have.
If people in the city of Virata question me, I will tell them that this is how I find pleasure."
Yudhishthira asked,

verse_data: किं वा त्वं तात कुर्वाणः प्रच्छन्नो विचरिष्यसि

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O Sahadeva! How will you find pleasure before him? O son! What task will you undertake? How will you disguise yourself while roaming there?"
Sahadeva replied,

verse_data: प्रतिषेद्धा च दोग्धा च संख्याने कुशलो गवाम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "I will tend to the cows of King Virata. I am skilled in tending to cattle, milking them and counting them.

verse_data: तन्तिपाल इति ख्यातो नाम्ना विदितमस्तु ते
निपुणं च चरिष्यामि व्येतु ते मानसो ज्वरः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Know that I will be called by the name of Tantipala. I will conduct myself skilfully and do not be anxious on my account.

verse_data: अहं हि भवता गोषु सततं प्रकृतः पुरा
तत्र मे कौशलं कर्म अवबुद्धं विशां पते

verse_translation.debroy_trans: In earlier times, you have naturally used me for tending to cattle. O lord of the earth! I am acquainted with all the skills connected with that task,

verse_data: लक्षणं चरितं चापि गवां यच्चापि मङ्गलम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: the traits and conduct of cattle and the auspicious marks. O lord of the earth! I know all this and other things extremely well.
O king! I know which bulls possess marks that deserve worship, and the smell of whose urine makes barren cows give birth.

verse_data: सोऽहमेवं चरिष्यामि प्रीतिरत्र हि मे सदा
न च मां वेत्स्यति परस्तत्ते रोचतु पार्थिव

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I will conduct myself in this way, for this always brings pleasure to me. O king! No one will be able to recognize me and you will be happy.
Yudhishthira said,

verse_data: इयं तु नः प्रिया भार्या प्राणेभ्योऽपि गरीयसी
मातेव परिपाल्या च पूज्या ज्येष्ठेव च स्वसा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "This is our beloved wife, dearer to us than our lives. She should be protected like a mother and worshipped like an elder sister.

verse_data: केन स्म कर्मणा कृष्णा द्रौपदी विचरिष्यति
न हि किंचिद्विजानाति कर्म कर्तुं यथा स्त्रियः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: What duty will Krishna Droupadi perform and how will she conduct herself? She is not familiar with any of the duties and tasks that women perform.

verse_data: सुकुमारी च बाला च राजपुत्री यशस्विनी

verse_translation.debroy_trans: She is delicate and young and is a famous princess. She is immensely fortunate and devoted to her husbands. How will she conduct herself?
Ever since birth, this beautiful one has known garlands, fragrances, ornaments and varied garments."
Droupadi replied,

verse_data: नैवमन्याः स्त्रियो यान्ति इति लोकस्य निश्चयः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O descendant of the Bharata lineage! In this world, there are unprotected maidservants known as sairandhri.
It is known to people that no other women conduct themselves in this fashion. If asked, I will call myself Sairandhri, adept at dressing the hair.

verse_data: सा रक्षिष्यति मां प्राप्तां मा ते भूद्दुःखमीदृशम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Concealing myself in this way, I will enter the service of Sudeshna, the king's famous wife. On obtaining me, she will protect me. Do not be unhappy in this way."
Yudhishthira said,

verse_data: कल्याणं भाषसे कृष्णे कुले जाता यथा वदेत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O Krishna! You speak well, deserving of one who has been born in a noble lineage. You do not know any sin. You are virtuous and always base yourself on righteous vows."
Yudhishthira said,
"You have stated the tasks and the duties that you will perform. To the best of my intelligence, I have decided that I approve of this.
Let our priest leave, together with the superintendents of the kitchen and the cooks, and preserve the agnihotra in Drupada's abode.

verse_data: यान्तु द्वारवतीं शीघ्रमिति मे वर्तते मतिः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: It is my view that Indrasena and the other charioteers should take the empty chariots and swiftly proceed to Dvaravati.
Let all the women who tend to Droupadi go to Panchala with the superintendents of the kitchen and the cooks.

verse_data: सर्वैरपि च वक्तव्यं न प्रज्ञायन्त पाण्डवाः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: All of them must say, "We do not know where the Pandavas are. All of them have deserted us and have left Dvaitavana."
Dhoumya said,
"Devoted well-wishers can speak about things that are known. Therefore, I will speak and listen to my reasons.

verse_data: यथा राजकुलं प्राप्य चरन्प्रेष्यो न रिष्यति

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O princes! I will tell you about life in a king's abode and about how, having reached the king's household, you can free yourselves from harm.
O Kouravyas! Life in a king's abode is difficult, even for those who are acquainted with it. For an entire year you will be unknown and will not be shown any honour, even though you deserve honour.

verse_data: दिष्टद्वारो लभेद्द्वारं न च राजसु विश्वसेत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: When you are shown the door, take to the door. Do not repose any trust in kings. Seek out seats that no one else desires.

verse_data: नास्य यानं न पर्यङ्कं न पीठं न गजं रथम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Live in the king's abode without assuming that, as a favourite, one can ascend his vehicle, palanquin, seat, elephant or chariot.
If evil-minded ones are suspicious of the seat that you occupy, do not ascend there again. That is the way one can live in a king's residence.
One should never offer advice to the king, unless he has asked for it. Be seated in silence and honour him at the right time.
Kings dislike those who disagree and people who speak lies.

verse_data: नैषां दारेषु कुर्वीत मैत्रीं प्राज्ञः कथंचन
अन्तःपुरचरा ये च द्वेष्टि यानहिताश्च ये

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Wise ones never become friendly with the wives, or with those who live in the inner quarters, or ill-wishers whom the king despises.

verse_data: एवं विचरतो राज्ञो न क्षतिर्जायते क्वचित्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: With the king's knowledge, one should perform the most insignificant of tasks. If one conducts oneself in this fashion, one will be protected from any harm from the king.
One should serve with the care one exhibits towards Agni or the other gods. There is no doubt that if one resorts to falsehood, one will confront violence.
One should follow the instructions of the lord and avoid negligence, pride and anger.

verse_data: समर्थनासु सर्वासु हितं च प्रियमेव च

verse_translation.debroy_trans: One should always offer advice that is good and pleasant, but one should attend more to the good than the pleasant.
In every kind of conversation, one should be kindly disposed. One should never say that which is unpleasant and brings no gain.

verse_data: अप्रमत्तश्च यत्तश्च हितं कुर्यात्प्रियं च यत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: A learned one serves, not thinking that he is favoured. Without any confusion, do that which is good and pleasant.

One can live in the king's abode as long as one does not serve those who wish him ill, as long as one does not consort with those who seek to harm him and as long as one does not stray from one's station.

verse_data: दक्षिणं वाथ वामं वा पार्श्वमासीत पण्डितः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: The learned seat themselves to the right side or the left. It has been decreed that the place behind him is for armed guards. The grand seat in front of him has always been forbidden.
One should not talk about prosperity in his presence. This is regarded as extreme impertinence, even among the poor.

verse_data: यं चासूयन्ति राजानः पुरुषं न वदेच्च तम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Do not reveal to men the lies the king utters. Do not converse with men the king does not like.

verse_data: शूरोऽस्मीति न दृप्तः स्याद्बुद्धिमानिति वा पुनः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Do not be proud because of your bravery, or vain because of your intelligence. One becomes dear and comfortable by doing that which brings pleasure to the king.

verse_data: ऐश्वर्यं प्राप्य दुष्प्रापं प्रियं प्राप्य च राजतः
अप्रमत्तो भवेद्राज्ञः प्रियेषु च हितेषु च

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Having obtained rare riches and affection from a king, without any confusion, one must engage in that which is good and pleasant for the king.
His anger can be a great obstacle. His favours can bring great fruits. Can anyone, who is honoured by the wise, think of causing harm to such a person?

verse_data: न चोष्ठौ निर्भुजेज्जातु न च वाक्यं समाक्षिपेत्
सदा क्षुतं च वातं च ष्ठीवनं चाचरेच्छनैः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: One should not forcefully move one's lips or thighs, or utter words with great force. Sneezing, breaking wind and clearing the throat should always be done gently.
When there is an occasion for laughter, one should laugh gently, and not like one who is mad.
But one should not be too solemn. Otherwise, one will be taken to be too severe. Instead, one should smile gently, showing oneself to be benevolent.

verse_data: असंमूढश्च यो नित्यं स राजवसतिं वसेत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: One can always live in a king's abode if one does not show delight at a gain or sorrow at a dishonour, and is always attentive.

verse_data: राजानं राजपुत्रं वा संवर्तयति यः सदा
अमात्यः पण्डितो भूत्वा स चिरं तिष्ठति श्रियम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: If one is a learned counsellor who always pleases the king and the prince, one can always live there in prosperity.

verse_data: न निर्बध्नाति राजानं लभते प्रग्रहं पुनः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: If a beloved adviser has fallen out of favour for some reason and does not blame the king, he will regain the favours once more.

verse_data: प्रत्यक्षं च परोक्षं च गुणवादी विचक्षणः
उपजीवी भवेद्राज्ञो विषये चापि यो वसेत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: One who earns his livelihood from the king, or dwells in his kingdom, must be sagacious enough to recount his good qualities, both in his presence and in his absence.

verse_data: अमात्यो हि बलाद्भोक्तुं राजानं प्रार्थयेत्तु यः
न स तिष्ठेच्चिरं स्थानं गच्छेच्च प्राणसंशयम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: An adviser who strongly desires to obtain some objective from the king, will not remain in that position for long and faces a danger to his life.

verse_data: श्रेयः सदात्मनो दृष्ट्वा परं राज्ञा न संवदेत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: For the sake of what is seen to be one's one gains, one should not say anything that goes against the king. In particular, one should always advice the king at the right place.
One who is always cheerful, strong, brave, faithful like a shadow, truthful, gentle and self-controlled, is capable of dwelling in a king's abode.

verse_data: अहं किं करवाणीति स राजवसतिं वसेत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: If another one is instructed with a task, a person who jumps forward and asks what he should do is capable of dwelling in a king's abode.

verse_data: उष्णे वा यदि वा शीते रात्रौ वा यदि वा दिवा
आदिष्टो न विकल्पेत स राजवसतिं वसेत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: If one does not waver when given instructions, whether it is hot or cold, or night or day, one is capable of dwelling in a king's abode.
One who lives away from home and does not remember one's loved ones and one who finds happiness in unhappiness is capable of dwelling in a king's abode.

verse_data: समवेषं न कुर्वीत नात्युच्चैः संनिधौ हसेत्
मन्त्रं न बहुधा कुर्यादेवं राज्ञः प्रियो भवेत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: One should not dress like him. One should not laugh loudly in his presence. One should not offer a great deal of advice. In this way, one will become dear to the king.

verse_data: प्राप्नोति हि हरन्द्रव्यं बन्धनं यदि वा वधम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Appointed to a task, one should not touch riches. Having obtained unearned riches, one faces imprisonment or death.
One should use vehicles, garments, ornaments and other objects that have been given, and thus become a greater favourite.
O sons! Spend a year in this way, adorning yourselves with good conduct. You will then regain your possessions and act according to your pleasures."
Yudhishthira replied,

verse_data: अनुशिष्टाः स्म भद्रं ते नैतद्वक्तास्ति कश्चन
कुन्तीमृते मातरं नो विदुरं च महामतिम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O fortunate one! We have been instructed by you. No one but you can speak in this fashion, but for our mother Kunti and the immensely intelligent Vidura.
It is now necessary to do what must be done, so that we can overcome our suffering and depart so as to achieve victory."
Vaishampayana said,
Having been thus addressed by the king, Dhoumya, supreme among brahmanas, performed all the decreed rites that were necessary for their departure.
He offered kindling to the fire and rendered oblations to the utterance of mantras, so that their prosperity might increase and they might conquer the earth.
The six of them, with Yajnaseni at the forefront, circumambulated the fire and the brahmanas, rich in austerities. Then they departed.
Vaishampayana said,
Those brave ones girded their swords and were armed with other weapons. Their quivers were tied. They had guards on their fingers and wrists. They proceeded towards the river Kalindi.
On foot, they arrived at its southern bank. The archers lived there, finding fortifications in the mountains and the forests.
The immensely strong great archers shot many different kinds of deer. To the north of Dasharna and the south of Panchala,
the Pandavas passed through Yakrilloma and Shurasena. Attired as hunters, they entered Matsya from the direction of the forest.
Having reached that country, Krishna told the king, "Behold. Many footpaths and different kinds of fields can be seen here.
It is clear that Virata's capital is still far away. My fatigue is extremely great.Let us spend the night here."
Yudhishthira replied,
"O Dhananjaya! O descendant of the Bharata lineage! Lift Panchali and carry her. Once we free ourselves from this forest, we will settle down in the capital."
Vaishampayana said
Like a king of elephants, Arjuna swiftly raised Droupadi up. Arjuna put her down when they reached the outskirts of the capital.
On arriving at the capital, Kounteya asked Arjuna, "Before entering the city, where will we keep our weapons?

verse_data: सायुधाश्च वयं तात प्रवेक्ष्यामः पुरं यदि

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O son! If we enter the city with our weapons, there is no doubt that we will create anxiety among the people.

verse_data: ततो द्वादश वर्षाणि प्रवेष्टव्यं वनं पुनः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: We have made a promise that even if one of us happens to be discovered, we will have to return to the forest again for twelve years."
Arjuna said,

verse_data: इयं कूटे मनुष्येन्द्र गहना महती शमी

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O Indra among men! On this peak and close to the cremation ground, there is a gigantic shami tree.

verse_data: न चापि विद्यते कश्चिन्मनुष्य इह पार्थिव

verse_translation.debroy_trans: It is impenetrable because of its fearsome branches and is difficult to climb. O king! Not a single man can be seen here. It is far away from the road and has grown in a forest frequented by animals and predators.
Let us hang up our weapons there and then proceed towards the city. O descendant of the Bharata lineage! We will then be able to enjoy ourselves as we please.
Vaishampayana said
O bull among the Bharata lineage! Having thus addressed King Dharmaraja Yudhishthira, he took off his weapons there.
With it, alone on a chariot, the one who had vanquished gods, men and snakes and conquered many opulent countries,
Partha, descendant of the Kuru lineage, loosened the string of the terrible Gandiva, which made a great roar and slaughtered masses of enemies.
Yudhishthira, the brave scorcher of enemies, loosened the bow's undecaying string, one with which he had protected Kurukshetra.
Lord Bhimasena loosened the string of the bow with which he had defeated the Panchalas in battle and with which, he alone, had conquered many enemies in the course of his conquest.

verse_data: निशम्य यस्य विस्फारं व्यद्रवन्त रणे परे

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Enemies were pacified in battle because of the twang of that bow. Mountains were rent asunder with the twang of his bow, which was like that of thunder.
O unblemished one! Bhimasena had used it to oppress the king of Saindhava.
The brave Pandava who had roared in battle, loosened the string of the bow with which he had conquered the west.
The brave lord Sahadeva, whose conduct was honest, loosened the string of the weapon with which he had conquered the southern direction.
With the bows, they laid down their long and yellow swords, their extremely expensive quivers and arrows that were as sharp as razors.
Ascending the tree, Nakula himself placed the bows in the places he considered to be firm and secure.

verse_data: यत्र चापश्यत स वै तिरो वर्षाणि वर्षति
तत्र तानि दृढैः पाशैः सुगाढं पर्यबन्धत

verse_translation.debroy_trans: He tied them firmly with strong nooses to those branches that were extremely strong and wide and where he saw that showers of rain would not enter.
The Pandavas also tied a dead body there, so that people would smell the stench of a corpse and avoid the shami tree from a distance.
They said, "This is our mother, who is one hundred and eighty years old. This is the dharma of our lineage, one that has been followed by our ancestors."
to the cowherds and herdsmen who questioned those scorchers of enemies. Then the Parthas approached the city.

verse_data: इति गुह्यानि नामानि चक्रे तेषां युधिष्ठिरः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Yudhishthira gave them the names they would secretly address each other by—Jaya, Jayanta, Vijaya, Jayatsena and Jayadbala.
In accordance with the promise that they had made, they entered the great city, to live in disguise in that kingdom for the thirteenth year.
Vaishampayana said,

verse_data: ततो विराटं प्रथमं युधिष्ठिरो; राजा सभायामुपविष्टमाव्रजत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: On his way to King Virata, who was seated in his assembly hall, Yudhishthira first fastened the dice, made of lapis lazuli and gold, to his side and gathered his garments around him.

The immensely famous lord of men, extender of the Kourava lineage, went to the extremely generous lord of the kingdom. He was worshipped by kings among men and was as difficult to approach as a venomous serpent.

He was a bull among men in his strength and beauty. He was grand and radiant, like an immortal. He was like the sun, enveloped in a great mass of clouds. The brave one was like the fire, covered in ashes.

verse_data: पप्रच्छ कोऽयं प्रथमं समेयिवा;ननेन योऽयं प्रसमीक्षते सभाम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: The Pandava approached, like the moon shrouded in clouds. On seeing this, King Virata questioned the advisers, brahmanas and vaishyas who were seated there. "Who is the one who has approached me, setting his eyes on my assembly hall for the first time?

verse_data: न तु द्विजोऽयं भविता नरोत्तमः; पतिः पृथिव्या इति मे मनोगतम्
न चास्य दासो न रथो न कुण्डले; समीपतो भ्राजति चायमिन्द्रवत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: This supreme among men cannot be a brahmana. It seems to me that he must be a lord of the earth, though he doesn't possess a servant, a chariot or an earring. When he nears, he is as resplendent as Indra.

verse_data: समीपमायाति च मे गतव्यथो; यथा गजस्तामरसीं मदोत्कटः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: It is my view that the marks on his body indicate that he is one whose head has been anointed. He approaches me without any hesitation, the way a rutting elephant nears a pond full of lotuses.

While he was thus reflecting, Yudhishthira, bull among men, approached Virata and spoke to him. "O emperor! Know that I am a brahmana who has lost everything and has come here in search of a livelihood.

verse_data: इहाहमिच्छामि तवानघान्तिके; वस्तुं यथा कामचरस्तथा विभो

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O unblemished one! O lord! I wish to live here with you, following your instructions." On hearing this, the king happily welcomed him. Thereafter, he spoke to him. "Please accept our homage.

verse_data: कामेन ताताभिवदाम्यहं त्वां; कस्यासि राज्ञो विषयादिहागतः
गोत्रं च नामापि च शंस तत्त्वतः; किं चापि शिल्पं तव विद्यते कृतम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O son! I am welcoming you with delight. Now tell me. From which king's dominion have you arrived here? Tell me truthfully, your name and your lineage. Which is the art that you wish to pursue here?"
Yudhishthira replied,

verse_data: युधिष्ठिरस्यासमहं पुरा सखा; वैयाघ्रपद्यः पुनरस्मि ब्राह्मणः
अक्षान्प्रवप्तुं कुशलोऽस्मि देविता; कङ्केति नाम्नास्मि विराट विश्रुतः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "In earlier times, I used to be Yudhishthira's friend. I am a brahmana from Vyaghrapada's lineage. I am skilled at throwing the dice and gambling. O Virata! I am known by the name of Kanka."
Virata said,

verse_data: ददामि ते हन्त वरं यमिच्छसि; प्रशाधि मत्स्यान्वशगो ह्यहं तव
प्रिया हि धूर्ता मम देविनः सदा; भवांश्च देवोपम राज्यमर्हति

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "I grant you the boon that you desire. Rule over Matsya and I will serve you. I have always loved skilled and shrewd gamblers. You are like a god and deserve a kingdom."
Yudhishthira replied,

verse_data: आप्तो विवादः परमो विशां पते; न विद्यते किंचन मत्स्य हीनतः
न मे जितः कश्चन धारयेद्धनं; वरो ममैषोऽस्तु तव प्रसादतः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O lord of the earth! O Matsya! If there is ever a great dispute, I will never accept the views of anyone who is inferior. But no one whom I defeat will retain his riches. Through your favours, please grant me this boon."
Virata said,

verse_data: शृण्वन्तु मे जानपदाः समागताः; कङ्को यथाहं विषये प्रभुस्तथा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "If anything unpleasant is done towards you, I will kill even those who should not be killed. If it is a brahmana, I will exile him from my kingdom. Let all the assembled citizens hear that Kanka is as much a lord of the kingdom as I am.

verse_data: समानयानो भवितासि मे सखा; प्रभूतवस्त्रो बहुपानभोजनः
पश्येस्त्वमन्तश्च बहिश्च सर्वदा; कृतं च ते द्वारमपावृतं मया

verse_translation.debroy_trans: You will be my friend and ride on the same vehicle. You will have many garments and a lot of food and drink. You will always look towards my inner and outer affairs. My door will always be open for you.

verse_data: ये त्वानुवादेयुरवृत्तिकर्शिता; ब्रूयाश्च तेषां वचनेन मे सदा
दास्यामि सर्वं तदहं न संशयो; न ते भयं विद्यति संनिधौ मम

verse_translation.debroy_trans: When oppressed people approach you in search of work, you can always give them word on my behalf. There is no doubt that I will give them everything that has been promised. In my presence, you will not find anything to be scared of."
Vaishampayana said

verse_data: एवं स लब्ध्वा तु वरं समागमं; विराटराजेन नरर्षभस्तदा
उवास वीरः परमार्चितः सुखी; न चापि कश्चिच्चरितं बुबोध तत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Having thus met King Virata and obtained the boon from him, the brave bull among men began to dwell there happily. He was shown the ultimate honours. No one there got to know about his true intentions.
Vaishampayana said,

verse_data: खजं च दर्वीं च करेण धारय;न्नसिं च कालाङ्गमकोशमव्रणम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: After that, another one arrived. He was terrible in strength and his beauty was resplendent. His gait was as easy as that of a valorous lion. He held a spoon and a ladle in his hands. He also had an unsheathed black and iron sword that was devoid of any blemishes.

verse_data: स सूदरूपः परमेण वर्चसा; रविर्यथा लोकमिमं प्रभासयन्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: He was in the form of a cook, but his radiance was supreme. He was like the sun illuminating the world. He was attired in extremely dark garments and was like the king of the mountains. He approached the king of Matsya and stood there.

verse_data: सिंहोन्नतांसोऽयमतीव रूपवा;न्प्रदृश्यते को नु नरर्षभो युवा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: On seeing the supreme one arrive, the king spoke to the assembled citizens. "Who is this handsome and young one whom we see? He is like a bull among men. His shoulders are as large as that of a lion.

verse_data: अदृष्टपूर्वः पुरुषो रविर्यथा; वितर्कयन्नास्य लभामि संपदम्
तथास्य चित्तं ह्यपि संवितर्कय;न्नरर्षभस्याद्य न यामि तत्त्वतः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I have not seen a man like him before. He is like the sun. Though I have been reflecting, I am unable to determine correctly the intentions of this bull among men."

verse_data: ततो विराटं समुपेत्य पाण्डवः; सुदीनरूपो वचनं महामनाः
उवाच सूदोऽस्मि नरेन्द्र बल्लवो; भजस्व मां व्यञ्जनकारमुत्तमम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Pandava then approached Virata. The great-minded one spoke in words that seemed to be despondent. "O Indra among men! I am a cook named Ballava. Appoint me and I will cook you supreme dishes."
Virata replied,

verse_data: न सूदतां मानद श्रद्दधामि ते; सहस्रनेत्रप्रतिमो हि दृश्यसे
श्रिया च रूपेण च विक्रमेण च; प्रभासि तातानवरो नरेष्विह

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "You are one who offers honour. I do not believe that you are a cook. You seem to be the equal of the thousand-eyed one, in your radiance, your beauty and your valour. O son! You are radiant and supreme among men."
Bhima said,

verse_data: नरेन्द्र सूदः परिचारकोऽस्मि ते; जानामि सूपान्प्रथमेन केवलान्
आस्वादिता ये नृपते पुराभव;न्युधिष्ठिरेणापि नृपेण सर्वशः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O Indra among men! I am a cook and your servant. I only know the best of dishes. O king! In earlier times, King Yudhishthira used to taste all of them.

verse_data: बलेन तुल्यश्च न विद्यते मया; नियुद्धशीलश्च सदैव पार्थिव
गजैश्च सिंहैश्च समेयिवानहं; सदा करिष्यामि तवानघ प्रियम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: There is no one who is equal to me in strength. O king! I have always been skilled at wrestling. O unblemished one! I will bring you pleasure by fighting with elephants and lions."
Virata replied,

verse_data: ददामि ते हन्त वरं महानसे; तथा च कुर्याः कुशलं हि भाषसे
न चैव मन्ये तव कर्म तत्समं; समुद्रनेमिं पृथिवीं त्वमर्हसि

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "I grant you the boon that you will be employed in the kitchen. You will work there, since you have said that you possess those skills. However, I do not think that this work is appropriate for you. You deserve the entire earth, girded by the ocean.

verse_data: यथा हि कामस्तव तत्तथा कृतं; महानसे त्वं भव मे पुरस्कृतः
नराश्च ये तत्र ममोचिताः पुरा; भवस्व तेषामधिपो मया कृतः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: But let it be the way you desire. You will be appointed the chief chef in the kitchen, heading the men who have been appointed there earlier by me."
Vaishampayana said

verse_data: तथा स भीमो विहितो महानसे; विराटराज्ञो दयितोऽभवद्दृढम्
उवास राजन्न च तं पृथग्जनो; बुबोध तत्रानुचरश्च कश्चन

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Thus Bhima was instated in the kitchen. He became a great favourite of King Virata's. O king! While he lived there, no one, not even the servants, got to know who he was.
Vaishampayana said,
Then the unblemished Krishna braided her hair, with curls at the tips. The mild and darkeyed one hid it on the right side

verse_data: कृत्वा वेषं च सैरन्ध्र्याः कृष्णा व्यचरदार्तवत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: and donned a garment that was long, dark and extremely dirty. She thus assumed the garb of a sairandhri and began to roam around, as if she was in great trouble.

verse_data: अपृच्छंश्चैव तां दृष्ट्वा का त्वं किं च चिकीर्षसि

verse_translation.debroy_trans: On seeing her wandering around, men and women rushed to her and asked, "Who are you and what do you desire?"

verse_data: कर्म चेच्छामि वै कर्तुं तस्य यो मां पुपुक्षति

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O Indra among kings! She then told them, "I am a sairandhri. I have come here, wishing to work for anyone who will feed me."

verse_data: तस्या रूपेण वेषेण श्लक्ष्णया च तथा गिरा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: On seeing her beauty, her attire and the gentleness of her speech, they did not believe that she was a maidservant who had come in search of food.
Virata's wife was the daughter of Kekaya and was greatly honoured. She looked down from the palace and beheld Drupada's daughter.

verse_data: समाहूयाब्रवीद्भद्रे का त्वं किं च चिकीर्षसि

verse_translation.debroy_trans: On seeing her in that state, without a protector and clad in a single piece of garment, she summoned her and said, "O fortunate one! Who are you and what do you wish to do?"

verse_data: कर्म चेच्छाम्यहं कर्तुं तस्य यो मां पुपुक्षति

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O Indra among kings! She told her, "I am a sairandhri and I have arrived here in search of work. I will work for anyone who feeds me."
Sudeshna replied,
"O beautiful one! Those you speak of do not possess the beauty you have. Those like you have many and varied servant maids and servants.
Your ankles are concealed. Your thighs are firm. You are deep in three places and high in six. You are red in the five places that should be red. Your voice is as slow as that of a swan.
You have beautiful hair and beautiful breasts. You are dark. Your buttocks and breasts are full. You are endowed with all the qualities, like a mare from Kashmira.
Your eyelashes curl gracefully. Your lips are like bimbas. You are slender at the waist. Your neck is lined like a conch shell. Your veins are hidden. Your face is like the full moon.

verse_data: का त्वं ब्रूहि यथा भद्रे नासि दासी कथंचन
यक्षी वा यदि वा देवी गन्धर्वी यदि वाप्सराः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O fortunate one! Tell me truthfully who you are. You cannot be a servant maid. Are you a yakshi, a goddess, a gandharvi or an apsara—

verse_data: इन्द्राणी वारुणी वा त्वं त्वष्टुर्धातुः प्रजापतेः
देव्यो देवेषु विख्यातास्तासां त्वं कतमा शुभे

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Alambusha, Mishrakeshi, Pundarika, Malini, Indrani, Varuni, or the consort of Tvashtra, Dhata or Prajapati? These goddesses are famous among the gods. Which of these are you?"
Droupadi replied,

verse_data: नास्मि देवी न गन्धर्वी नासुरी न च राक्षसी

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "I am not a goddess, or a gandharvi, or an asuri, or a rakshasi. I tell you truthfully that I am a sairandhri.
I know how to dress hair and am skilful at grinding unguents. I can weave extremely beautiful and colourful garlands.
I served Satyabhama, Krishna's beloved queen and Krishna, the wife of the Pandus and the solitary beauty in the Kuru lineage.
I go wherever I can obtain a good life. I am happy as long as I can obtain excellent garments.

verse_data: मालिनीत्येव मे नाम स्वयं देवी चकार सा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: The goddess herself used to call me by the name of Malini. O goddess! O Sudeshna! I have arrived thus in your house."
Sudeshna said,

verse_data: मूर्ध्नि त्वां वासयेयं वै संशयो मे न विद्यते
नो चेदिह तु राजा त्वां गच्छेत्सर्वेण चेतसा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "There is no doubt that I can place you on my head, as long as the king does not desire you with all his heart and go to you.

verse_data: स्त्रियो राजकुले पश्य याश्चेमा मम वेश्मनि
प्रसक्तास्त्वां निरीक्षन्ते पुमांसं कं न मोहयेः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Behold! The ladies of the royal lineage and those who live in my abode are gazing at you with attachment. What man will you not infatuate?

verse_data: तेऽपि त्वां संनमन्तीव पुमांसं कं न मोहयेः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Behold! Even the trees that are established in my abode are bending down over you. What man will you not infatuate?
When King Virata sees your superhuman beauty, with the beautiful buttocks and the beautiful hips, he will forsake me and go to you with all his heart.
Your limbs are flawless. Your eyes are soft and long. O one with the beautiful smiles! On looking at you, any man who sees you will become attached and be overcome with desire.
You are unblemished in all your limbs and he will come under the sway of the god of love.
A she-crab conceives and brings about her own death. O one with the beautiful smiles! I think that if I grant you residence, I will bring about my own destruction."
Droupadi replied,

verse_data: नास्मि लभ्या विराटेन न चान्येन कथंचन
गन्धर्वाः पतयो मह्यं युवानः पञ्च भामिनि

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O beautiful one! Neither Virata, nor anyone else, can ever obtain me. I have five young gandharvas as my husbands.

verse_data: रक्षन्ति ते च मां नित्यं दुःखाचारा तथा न्वहम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: They are the sons of a gandharva king who is extremely powerful. They always protect me. Any conduct that brings me grief ensures destruction.

verse_data: यो मे न दद्यादुच्छिष्टं न च पादौ प्रधावयेत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: My gandharva husbands allow me to live in a house where I am not served any leftover food and where I am not asked to wash anyone's feet.

verse_data: यो हि मां पुरुषो गृध्येद्यथान्याः प्राकृतस्त्रियः
तामेव स ततो रात्रिं प्रविशेदपरां तनुम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: If any man desires me, like any other common woman, before the night is over, he will enter another body.

verse_data: दुःखशीला हि गन्धर्वास्ते च मे बलवत्तराः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O beautiful one! No one is capable of making me stray. Those powerful gandharvas always protect me from unhappiness."
Sudeshna said,

verse_data: एवं त्वां वासयिष्यामि यथा त्वं नन्दिनीच्छसि
न च पादौ न चोच्छिष्टं स्प्रक्ष्यसि त्वं कथंचन

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O beloved one! I will then offer you residence, according to your desires. You will not wash the feet of others. Nor will you ever eat leftover food."
Vaishampayana said,
Krishna was thus comforted by Virata's wife. O Janamejaya! No one there got to know who she actually was.
Vaishampayana said,
Having donned the supreme garments of a cowherd, Sahadeva also arrived. He adopted their language and presented himself before Virata.
The king saw that resplendent bull among men arriving, and advancing towards the descendant of the Kuru lineage, asked him,

verse_data: कस्य वा त्वं कुतो वा त्वं किं वा तात चिकीर्षसि
न हि मे दृष्टपूर्वस्त्वं तत्त्वं ब्रूहि नरर्षभ

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "Whom do you belong to and where have you come from? O son! What do you wish for? O bull among men! Tell me truthfully. I have not seen you before."
When he arrived before the king, Sahadeva, the destroyer of enemies, spoke in a voice that was as deep as the clouds.

verse_data: वस्तुं त्वयीच्छामि विशां वरिष्ठ; तान्राजसिंहान्न हि वेद्मि पार्थान्
न शक्यते जीवितुमन्यकर्मणा; न च त्वदन्यो मम रोचते नृपः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "I am a vaishya by the name of Arishtanemi. I used to number the cows for the bulls among the Kurus. O supreme one on earth! I wish to reside with you. I do not know where the Parthas, lions among kings, are. I know of no other means of livelihood. O king! I will not find pleasure in serving anyone other than you."
Virata replied,

verse_data: त्वं ब्राह्मणो यदि वा क्षत्रियोऽसि; समुद्रनेमीश्वररूपवानसि
आचक्ष्व मे तत्त्वममित्रकर्शन; न वैश्यकर्म त्वयि विद्यते समम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "You must be a brahmana or a kshatriya. You are as handsome as a lord of the earth, with the frontiers of the ocean. O destroyer of enemies! Tell me the truth. The duties of a vaishya are not appropriate for you.

verse_data: कस्यासि राज्ञो विषयादिहागतः; किं चापि शिल्पं तव विद्यते कृतम्
कथं त्वमस्मासु निवत्स्यसे सदा; वदस्व किं चापि तवेह वेतनम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: From what king's kingdom have you arrived here? What kind of craftsmanship do you wish to pursue? In what capacity will you always reside with us? Tell me what salary you wish to be paid."
Sahadeva said,
"King Yudhishthira is the eldest among the five sons of Pandu. He possessed herds of eight hundred, one thousand, ten thousand,

verse_data: तेषां गोसंख्य आसं वै तन्तिपालेति मां विदुः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: another ten thousand and another twenty thousand cows. I was the one who numbered his cows and I was known by the name of Tantipala.

verse_data: भूतं भव्यं भविष्यच्च यच्च संख्यागतं क्वचित्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Nothing is unknown to me about numbering—the past, the present and the future, and within a distance of ten yojanas.

verse_data: आसीच्च स मया तुष्टः कुरुराजो युधिष्ठिरः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: The great-souled one, Yudhishthira, king of the Kuru lineage, was well acquainted with my skills and was always satisfied with me.

verse_data: क्षिप्रं हि गावो बहुला भवन्ति; न तासु रोगो भवतीह कश्चित्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I know how cattle can be multiplied swiftly and how one ensures that they never suffer from disease. These types of skills have always been known to me. Such craftsmanship has always been established in me.
O king! I know the auspicious marks of bulls, the smell of whose urine makes barren cows give birth."
Virata replied,

verse_data: शतं सहस्राणि समाहितानि; वर्णस्य वर्णस्य विनिश्चिता गुणैः
पशून्सपालान्भवते ददाम्यहं; त्वदाश्रया मे पशवो भवन्त्विह

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "I possess one hundred thousand. They have been classified according to colours and other qualities that are yet undetected. I put you in charge of the animals and the herdsmen. Henceforth, let my animals be in your care."
Vaishampayana said

verse_data: तथा स राज्ञोऽविदितो विशां पते; उवास तत्रैव सुखं नरेश्वरः
न चैनमन्येऽपि विदुः कथंचन; प्रादाच्च तस्मै भरणं यथेप्सितम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O lord of the earth! Thus, unknown to the king, that supreme among men lived there happily. No one else found out who he was. He was also paid a salary, according to his wishes.
Vaishampayana said,

verse_data: प्राकारवप्रे प्रतिमुच्य कुण्डले; दीर्घे च कम्बू परिहाटके शुभे

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Then another handsome one made his appearance. He was a giant man, but was adorned in the ornaments of women. He wore earrings that were as large as walls and turrets, made out of long and beautiful conch shells adorned with gold.

His long and abundant hair was combed. He was mighty-armed and his valour was like that of an elephant. The earth trembled as he advanced. He approached Virata, who was seated in his assembly hall, an oppressor of enemies who had disguised himself.

verse_data: विराजमानं परमेण वर्चसा; सुतं महेन्द्रस्य गजेन्द्रविक्रमम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: However, his supreme radiance was dazzling. This was the son of the great Indra, and like a king of elephants in his valour. On seeing him arrive in the assembly hall,

verse_data: सर्वानपृच्छच्च समीपचारिणः; कुतोऽयमायाति न मे पुरा श्रुतः
न चैनमूचुर्विदितं तदा नराः; सविस्मितं वाक्यमिदं नृपोऽब्रवीत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: the king asked all those who were nearby, "Where has he come from? I have not heard of him before." But none of the men there said that they knew him. In amazement, the king spoke these words.

verse_data: सर्वोपपन्नः पुरुषो मनोरमः; श्यामो युवा वारणयूथपोपमः
विमुच्य कम्बू परिहाटके शुभे; विमुच्य वेणीमपिनह्य कुण्डले

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "You are a beautiful man and have all the endowments. You are dark and young and are equal to the leader of a herd of elephants. You wear beautiful conch shells that are adorned with gold. You have loosened your hair in a braid and are adorned with earrings.

verse_data: शिखी सुकेशः परिधाय चान्यथा; भवस्व धन्वी कवची शरी तथा
आरुह्य यानं परिधावतां भवा;न्सुतैः समो मे भव वा मया समः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Your hair is peaked and abundant. But your attire seems to be wrong. You must be an archer, with armour and arrows. Climb onto a swift vehicle. Be like my sons, or like me myself.

verse_data: वृद्धो ह्यहं वै परिहारकामः; सर्वान्मत्स्यांस्तरसा पालयस्व
नैवंविधाः क्लीबरूपा भवन्ति; कथंचनेति प्रतिभाति मे मनः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I am an old man now and wish to ease my burdens. Swiftly protect the entire region of Matsya. Someone with your form cannot be a eunuch. It seems to my mind that there is no way this can be true."
Arjuna replied,

verse_data: गायामि नृत्याम्यथ वादयामि; भद्रोऽस्मि नृत्ते कुशलोऽस्मि गीते
त्वमुत्तरायाः परिदत्स्व मां स्वयं; भवामि देव्या नरदेव नर्तकः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "I sing, dance and play musical instruments. I am excellent in dancing and skilled in singing. O god among men! Give me Uttara. I will myself be the dancer to that goddess.

verse_data: इदं तु रूपं मम येन किं नु त;त्प्रकीर्तयित्वा भृशशोकवर्धनम्
बृहन्नडां वै नरदेव विद्धि मां; सुतं सुतां वा पितृमातृवर्जिताम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: There is no point in recounting how I came by this form. It will only increase my misery. O god among men! Know my name to be Brihannada. I have been abandoned by my father and my mother as a son and a daughter.
Virata said,

verse_data: ददामि ते हन्त वरं बृहन्नडे; सुतां च मे नर्तय याश्च तादृशीः
इदं तु ते कर्म समं न मे मतं; समुद्रनेमिं पृथिवीं त्वमर्हसि

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O Brihannada! I will grant you the boon that you have asked for. Instruct my daughter, and others like her, in dance. I do not think that such a duty befits you. You deserve the entire earth, up to the frontiers of the ocean."
Vaishampayana said,

verse_data: बृहन्नडां तामभिवीक्ष्य मत्स्यरा;ट्कलासु नृत्ते च तथैव वादिते
अपुंस्त्वमप्यस्य निशम्य च स्थिरं; ततः कुमारीपुरमुत्ससर्ज तम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Having tested Brihannada in dancing, music and other arts, and on determining that he was a eunuch, the king of Matsya permitted him to enter the quarters of the princess.

verse_data: स शिक्षयामास च गीतवादितं; सुतां विराटस्य धनंजयः प्रभुः
सखीश्च तस्याः परिचारिकास्तथा; प्रियश्च तासां स बभूव पाण्डवः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Lord Dhananjaya instructed Virata's daughter in singing and music, as well as her friends and attendants. Pandava became very dear to them.

verse_data: तथा स सत्रेण धनंजयोऽवस;त्प्रियाणि कुर्वन्सह ताभिरात्मवान्
तथागतं तत्र न जज्ञिरे जना; बहिश्चरा वाप्यथ वान्तरेचराः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Self-controlled Dhananjaya lived there in disguise and did what pleased them. No one there, outside or in the inner quarters, got to know about him.
Vaishampayana said,
Then another lordly Pandava was seen to approach King Virata, when he was inspecting his horses. As he arrived, the people saw him, like the disc of the sun freed from behind the clouds.

verse_data: स वै हयानैक्षत तांस्ततस्ततः; समीक्षमाणं च ददर्श मत्स्यराट्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: He began to examine the horses that were in every direction. On seeing him engaged in examining, the king of Matsya, the destroyer of enemies, spoke to his attendants thus.

verse_data: अयं हयान्वीक्षति मामकान्दृढं; ध्रुवं हयज्ञो भविता विचक्षणः
प्रवेश्यतामेष समीपमाशु मे; विभाति वीरो हि यथामरस्तथा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "This man is an equal of the immortals. Where has he come from? He is examining my horses with great thoroughness. It is certain that he is skilled in the knowledge of horses. Let him swiftly be brought before me. This brave one's appearance is like that of an immortal."

verse_data: अभ्येत्य राजानममित्रहाब्रवी;ज्जयोऽस्तु ते पार्थिव भद्रमस्तु च
हयेषु युक्तो नृप संमतः सदा; तवाश्वसूतो निपुणो भवाम्यहम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: The destroyer of enemies now spoke to the king. "O king! O fortunate one! May you be victorious. O king! I have always been esteemed because of my knowledge of horses. I will become the skilled charioteer of your horses."
Virata replied,

verse_data: ददामि यानानि धनं निवेशनं; ममाश्वसूतो भवितुं त्वमर्हसि
कुतोऽसि कस्यासि कथं त्वमागतः; प्रब्रूहि शिल्पं तव विद्यते च यत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "I will give you vehicles, riches and a house. You deserve to be the charioteer of my horses. But where have you come from and whom do you belong to? Why have you come here? Tell me about the arts that are known to you."
Nakula said,
"King Yudhishthira is the eldest of the five sons of Pandu. O destroyer of enemies! I was earlier employed as the tender of his horses.

verse_data: अश्वानां प्रकृतिं वेद्मि विनयं चापि सर्वशः
दुष्टानां प्रतिपत्तिं च कृत्स्नं चैव चिकित्सितम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I know the nature of horses and everything about subduing them. I can control wicked ones and I know everything about healing them.

verse_data: न कातरं स्यान्मम जातु वाहनं; न मेऽस्ति दुष्टा वडवा कुतो हयाः
जनस्तु मामाह स चापि पाण्डवो; युधिष्ठिरो ग्रन्थिकमेव नामतः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: No steed that belongs to me is ever timid. No mare of mine is wicked, not to speak of stallions. People, and Pandava Yudhishthira, knew me by the name of Granthika."
Virata replied,

verse_data: यदस्ति किंचिन्मम वाजिवाहनं; तदस्तु सर्वं त्वदधीनमद्य वै
ये चापि केचिन्मम वाजियोजका;स्त्वदाश्रयाः सारथयश्च सन्तु मे

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "From today, let all the horses and mounts that I possess be entrusted to your care. Let all my charioteers, and all those who yoke horses, be subordinate to you from now on.

verse_data: इदं तवेष्टं यदि वै सुरोपम; ब्रवीहि यत्ते प्रसमीक्षितं वसु
न तेऽनुरूपं हयकर्म विद्यते; प्रभासि राजेव हि संमतो मम

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O one who is like the gods! Tell me what you wish for. What kind of salary do you desire? The tending of horses does not become you. It seems to me that you are as radiant as a king.

verse_data: युधिष्ठिरस्येव हि दर्शनेन मे; समं तवेदं प्रियदर्श दर्शनम्
कथं तु भृत्यैः स विनाकृतो वने; वसत्यनिन्द्यो रमते च पाण्डवः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: To me, your appearance is as pleasant as that of Yudhishthira himself. How can the Pandava find any pleasure dwelling in the forest, without any servants?"
Vaishampayana said

verse_data: तथा स गन्धर्ववरोपमो युवा; विराटराज्ञा मुदितेन पूजितः
न चैनमन्येऽपि विदुः कथंचन; प्रियाभिरामं विचरन्तमन्तरा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Thus the young one, who was like the best of the gandharvas, was happily honoured by King Virata. No one got to know about him and he roamed around, making himself agreeable.

verse_data: एवं हि मत्स्ये न्यवसन्त पाण्डवा; यथाप्रतिज्ञाभिरमोघदर्शनाः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Thus did the Pandavas, whose sight always bore fruit, dwell in Matsya, following the pledge that they had given. They lived a careful life of concealment. But the lords of the earth, up to the frontiers of the ocean, were extremely miserable.
Janamejaya asked,

verse_data: अत ऊर्ध्वं महावीर्याः किमकुर्वन्त वै द्विज

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O brahmana! While the Pandavas resided in the city of Matsya, what did the extremely valorous Pandavas do?' Vaishampayana said,
Vaishampayana said
While the descendants of the Kuru lineage lived there in disguise, honoured by the king, listen to what they did.

verse_data: तथैव च विराटस्य सपुत्रस्य विशां पते

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O lord of the earth! As a courtier, Yudhishthira became the beloved of others in the assembly, as well as of Virata and his son.
Pandava knew the heart of the dice and played with the dice as he pleased, as if they were birds tied to a string.

verse_data: अज्ञातं च विराटस्य विजित्य वसु धर्मराट्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Unknown to Virata, Dharmaraja, tiger among men, distributed the riches that he won among his brothers, to each one according to what he deserved.
Bhimasena sold Yudhishthira meat and other kinds of food that were given by Matsya.
Arjuna sold the old garments that he obtained from the inner quarters and passed on all the proceeds to the Pandavas.

verse_data: दधि क्षीरं घृतं चैव पाण्डवेभ्यः प्रयच्छति

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Pandava Sahadeva assumed the attire of a cowherd. He gave the Pandavas curds, milk and ghee.

verse_data: नकुलोऽपि धनं लब्ध्वा कृते कर्मणि वाजिनाम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Because of his duties with the horses, Nakula satisfied the lord of men and obtained riches. He gave this to the Pandavas.
The ascetic Krishna looked after all the brothers. The beautiful one acted so that they might remain undetected.
O lord of men! Thus the maharathas looked after each other, living in disguise, but looking after Krishna.

verse_data: अथ मासे चतुर्थे तु ब्रह्मणः सुमहोत्सवः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: There was a great festival of austerities in Matysa in the fourth month. Men honoured it and celebrated it with great expense.
O king! Thousands of wrestlers arrived there from all the directions. They were gigantic in size and immensely valorous, like Kalakhanja asuras.

They were insolent of their valour and were proud of their strength and were honoured by the king. Their shoulders, waists and necks were like those of lions. They were free from dirt and were in great spirits. Before the king, they had been victorious and honoured in the arena earlier.
There was a gigantic one among them and he challenged all the wrestlers. As he strode around the arena, not a single one dared to take him on.

verse_data: अथ सूदेन तं मल्लं योधयामास मत्स्यराट्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: When all the other wrestlers were despondent and had lost their spirits, the king of Matsya asked his cook to fight with the wrestler.

verse_data: न हि शक्नोति विवृते प्रत्याख्यातुं नराधिपम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Thus instructed, Bhima was unable to refuse the king in public and unhappily made up his mind.
That tiger among men entered the giant arena with the light gait of a tiger and brought delight to Virata.
To the delight of the assembly, Kounteya girded himself. Bhima then challenged the wrestler, who was like Vritra himself.
Both of them were extremely energetic and both of them were terrible in their valour. They were intoxicated, like giant elephants that were sixty years old.
Bhima, the destroyer of enemies, grasped the roaring wrestler and tugged him with his arms. He also roared like a tiger seizing an elephant.

verse_data: ततो मल्लाश्च मत्स्याश्च विस्मयं चक्रिरे परम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Then the mighty-armed and brave Bhima raised the wrestler up and whirled him around, to the supreme amazement of the other wrestlers and the residents of Matsya.
Having whirled him around a hundred times, until he lost his mind and his senses, the mighty-armed Vrikodara flung him down on the ground.
The brave Jimuta, famous in the world, was thus slain. Together with his relatives, Virata was greatly delighted.
In his joy, the great-minded king gave a lot of riches to Ballava in that great arena, like Vaishravana.
After having defeated a large number of wrestlers and immensely strong men in the same way, he obtained the supreme of favours from the king of Matsya.

verse_data: यदास्य तुल्यः पुरुषो न कश्चित्तत्र विद्यते

verse_translation.debroy_trans: No other man could be found who was a match for him. He was then made to fight with tigers, lions and elephants.
In the presence of the women from the inner quarters, Virata repeatedly made Vrikodara fight with angry lions that were extremely powerful.
Pandava Bibhatsu satisfied Virata and all the women from the inner quarters with his singing and his excellent dancing.
O supreme among kings! Nakula satisfied the king with the trained and swift steeds that he assembled there.

verse_data: तस्मै प्रदेयं प्रायच्छत्प्रीतो राजा धनं बहु

verse_translation.debroy_trans: On seeing Sahadeva's trained bulls, the king was delighted and gave him a lot of riches.
Thus did those bulls among men live there in disguise.They performed various duties for King Virata.
Vaishampayana said,
The maharatha Parthas lived in disguise in the city of Matsya and ten months elapsed.

verse_data: याज्ञसेनी सुदेष्णां तु शुश्रूषन्ती विशां पते

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O lord of the earth! O Janamejaya! Yajnaseni lived there in great unhappiness, serving Sudeshna, though she deserved to be served herself.
Virata's general saw the lotus-eyed Panchali roaming around in Sudeshna's abode.
As soon as he saw her roaming around like a goddess, like a daughter of the gods, Kichaka desired her and was oppressed by the arrows of love.
Burning with the fire of desire, the general went to Sudeshna and smilingly said,

verse_data: नेयं पुरा जातु मयेह दृष्टा; राज्ञो विराटस्य निवेशने शुभा
रूपेण चोन्मादयतीव मां भृशं; गन्धेन जाता मदिरेव भामिनी

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "I have not seen this beautiful one in Virata's abode earlier. This beautiful one's form intoxicates me, like scent generated from liquor.

verse_data: का देवरूपा हृदयंगमा शुभे; आचक्ष्व मे का च कुतश्च शोभना
चित्तं हि निर्मथ्य करोति मां वशे; न चान्यदत्रौषधमद्य मे मतम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O beautiful one! Who is this one who steals the heart, with the form of a goddess? O beautiful one! Where has she come from and whom does she belong to? She oppresses my mind and has brought me under her control. I think that there is no medicine that can cure me now.

verse_data: अहो तवेयं परिचारिका शुभा; प्रत्यग्ररूपा प्रतिभाति मामियम्
अयुक्तरूपं हि करोति कर्म ते; प्रशास्तु मां यच्च ममास्ति किंचन

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Behold! It seems to me that your beautiful serving maid possesses extreme beauty. It is not fitting that she should work for you. She should command me and everything that I possess.

Let her grace my beautiful and grand residence, with all its many elephants, horses, chariots, great riches and opulence, with a lot of food and drink and with its handsome gold and colourful adornments."
After consulting Sudeshna, Kichaka went to the daughter of the king and spoke to Krishna in a comforting voice, like a jackal confronting a queen of deer in the forest.

verse_data: इदं च रूपं प्रथमं च ते वयो; निरर्थकं केवलमद्य भामिनि
अधार्यमाणा स्रगिवोत्तमा यथा; न शोभसे सुन्दरि शोभना सती

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O beautiful one! Your supreme form and your youth are useless if you are alone, like a beautiful garland that is not worn. O beautiful one! Though you are handsome, you are lacking in radiance.

verse_data: त्यजामि दारान्मम ये पुरातना; भवन्तु दास्यस्तव चारुहासिनि
अहं च ते सुन्दरि दासवत्स्थितः; सदा भविष्ये वशगो वरानने

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O one with the beautiful smile! I will give up the wives I have had before. O beautiful one! I will station myself as your servant. O one with the beautiful face! I will always be under your control."
Droupadi replied,
"O son of a suta! You desire me. But I am not one who should be coveted. I am a sairandhri, born from an inferior lineage. I am terrible to look at and I perform the duty of dressing hair.

verse_data: परदारास्मि भद्रं ते न युक्तं त्वयि सांप्रतम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O fortunate one! I am another one's wife. This conduct is beneath you. Wives are loved by all beings. Think of what is dharma.

verse_data: परदारे न ते बुद्धिर्जातु कार्या कथंचन

verse_translation.debroy_trans: In no way should your mind turn towards another one's wife. Men who are good in their vows always avoid that which should be abhorred.
Men who are evil-souled and overcome by delusion covet that which should not be coveted and attain ill fame. They confront grave danger.

verse_data: मा सूतपुत्र हृष्यस्व माद्य त्यक्ष्यसि जीवितम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O son of a suta! Do not rejoice. Otherwise, you may lose your life today, by desiring that which is difficult to obtain. I am protected by brave ones.

verse_data: न चाप्यहं त्वया शक्या गन्धर्वाः पतयो मम
ते त्वां निहन्युः कुपिताः साध्वलं मा व्यनीनशः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I cannot be obtained by you. My husbands are gandharvas. They will be angered and will kill you.
Cease and do not bring about your own destruction. You desire to traverse a path that men cannot walk on. You are like a stupid child who is on a bank and wants to cross over to the other bank.

verse_data: अन्तर्महीं वा यदि वोर्ध्वमुत्पतेः; समुद्रपारं यदि वा प्रधावसि
तथापि तेषां न विमोक्षमर्हसि; प्रमाथिनो देवसुता हि मे वराः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: You may enter the earth, or you may rise up into the sky. You may flee to the furthest shore of the ocean. But you will not be able to free yourself from them. My husbands are the powerful sons of the gods.

verse_data: त्वं कालरात्रीमिव कश्चिदातुरः; किं मां दृढं प्रार्थयसेऽद्य कीचक
किं मातुरङ्के शयितो यथा शिशु;श्चन्द्रं जिघृक्षुरिव मन्यसे हि माम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O Kichaka! You firmly desire me now, as if you are ill and the night of your death has arrived. You desire me, like a child who is asleep on his mother's lap and wishes to obtain the moon."
Vaishampayana said,
Having been thus turned down by the princess, Kichaka was overcome by a terrible lust that could not be controlled.
He went to Sudeshna and told her, "O Kaikeyi! Act so that I can be united with Sairandhri. O Sudeshna! Otherwise, I will give up my life."

verse_data: तस्य तां बहुशः श्रुत्वा वाचं विलपतस्तदा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Hearing his many lamentations, the goddess who was Virata's queen felt compassion for him.
She debated in her mind and thought about what would best serve her purpose, regarding Krishna. Sudeshna then told the suta,

verse_data: पर्विणीं त्वं समुद्दिश्य सुरामन्नं च कारय

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "Have some liquor and food prepared for the festive day. On that day, I will send her to you, asking her to fetch some liquor for me.
Thus sent, without any obstructions, you can try to seduce her in private, comforting her according to your desires and uniting with her, if she agrees."
Hearing these words of his sister, Kichaka returned home. He procured supremely refined liquor, fit to be served to a king.
He made his excellent cooks prepare the meat of goat and lambs, large quantities of the meat of deer and supreme food and drink.
Once this was done, having been informed by Kichaka, Queen Sudeshna sent Sairandhri to Kichaka's residence.
Sudeshna said,
"O Sairandhri! Arise and go to Kichaka's house. O fortunate one! I am overcome by thirst. Go and fetch me something to drink."
Droupadi replied,

verse_data: त्वमेव राज्ञि जानासि यथा स निरपत्रपः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O princess! I will not go to his residence. O queen! You know that he has no shame.
O one with the unblemished limbs! O beautiful one! I will not be addicted to desire in your house and I will not be unfaithful to my husbands.

verse_data: त्वं चैव देवि जानासि यथा स समयः कृतः
प्रविशन्त्या मया पूर्वं तव वेश्मनि भामिनि

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O goddess! O beautiful one! You know about the conditions I set when I entered your house earlier.

verse_data: सोऽवमंस्यति मां दृष्ट्वा न यास्ये तत्र शोभने

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O one with the beautiful hair! Kichaka is a fool and is insolent with desire. On seeing me, he will cause me dishonour. O beautiful one! I will not go there.

verse_data: अन्यां प्रेषय भद्रं ते स हि मामवमंस्यते

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O princess! You have many other servant maids who follow your instructions. O fortunate one! Send one of them instead. It is certain that he will dishonour me."
Sudeshna replied,

verse_data: नैव त्वां जातु हिंस्यात्स इतः संप्रेषितां मया

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "If you have been sent by me, he will not cause any violence to you."
Vaishampayana said
With these words, she gave her a golden goblet with a cover. Anxious and weeping and seeking protection with fate, she left for Kichaka's house to fetch the liquor.
Droupadi said,

verse_data: तेन सत्येन मां प्राप्तां कीचको मा वशे कृथाः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "If it is true that I do not know anyone other than the Pandus, then through that truth, let Kichaka not be able to overpower me when I reach that place."
Vaishampayana said
Then the weak one worshipped Surya for an instant. Surya got to know everything from the slender-waisted one and instructed an invisible rakshasa to protect her.
Under no circumstances was the rakshasa supposed to leave the side of the unblemished one.

verse_data: तां मृगीमिव वित्रस्तां दृष्ट्वा कृष्णां समीपगाम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: On seeing Krishna approach like a frightened doe, the suta arose, as if one wishing to cross a river has found a boat.
Kichaka said,

verse_data: स्वागतं ते सुकेशान्ते सुव्युष्टा रजनी मम

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O one with the beautiful hair! Welcome. My night has happily turned into day. I have obtained you as my mistress. Do what brings me pleasure.
Let them bring golden garlands, conch shells, earrings made out of gold, silken garments and other skins.

verse_data: एहि तत्र मया सार्धं पिबस्व मधुमाधवीम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I have arranged that a divine bed should be spread out for you. Come with me there and drink the honeyed liquor.
Droupadi replied,

verse_data: पानमानय मे क्षिप्रं पिपासा मेति चाब्रवीत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "The princess has sent me to you to fetch liquor. She told me she was thirsty and I should quickly fetch her something to drink."
Kichaka said,
"Some other fortunate one will take refined liquor to the princess."
Vaishampayana said,

Having said this, the suta's son grasped her by the right hand. Having been thus seized, she threw Kichaka down on the floor. She rushed to the assembly hall where King Yudhishthira was seated and sought protection.
Kichaka pursued the fleeing one and grasped her by the hair. While the king looked on, he flung her down and kicked her with his foot.
O descendant of the Bharata lineage! However, the rakshasa who had been employed by the sun god pushed Kichaka away with the force of the wind.
Struck by the strength of the rakshasa, he fell down on the ground. He was whirled around and was motionless, like a tree that has been uprooted.
Both Bhimasena and Yudhishthira were seated there and looked on. They could not bear the sight of Krishna being kicked by Kichaka.
The great-minded Bhima wished to kill the evil-minded Kichaka and gnashed his teeth in anger.
O king! But Dharmaraja restrained Bhima by pressing his thumb with his own.
She was weeping and clung to the door of the assembly hall. The one with the beautiful hips glanced at her husbands, whose appearances were dejected.
She was also bent on protecting the pledge they had taken in the name of dharma. With terrible eyes that seemed to burn down, she told Matsya,
Droupadi said,

verse_data: येषां वैरी न स्वपिति पदा भूमिमुपस्पृशन्
तेषां मां मानिनीं भार्यां सूतपुत्रः पदावधीत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "I am the revered wife of those whose enemies do not dare to sleep when they traverse the earth. The son of a suta has kicked me with his foot.

verse_data: तेषां मां मानिनीं भार्यां सूतपुत्रः पदावधीत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I am the revered wife of those who give and do not ask, those who are truthful and are like brahmanas. The son of a suta has kicked me with his foot.

verse_data: तेषां मां मानिनीं भार्यां सूतपुत्रः पदावधीत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I am the revered wife of those whose war drums and bow twangs are continually heard. The son of a suta has kicked me with his foot.

verse_data: तेषां मां मानिनीं भार्यां सूतपुत्रः पदावधीत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I am the revered wife of those who are energetic and self-controlled, who are powerful and extremely proud. The son of a suta has kicked me with his foot.

verse_data: तेषां मां मानिनीं भार्यां सूतपुत्रः पदावधीत्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I am the revered wife of those who, had they not been bound by the noose of dharma, are capable of destroying the entire world. The son of a suta has kicked me with his foot.

verse_data: चरन्ति लोके प्रच्छन्नाः क्व नु तेऽद्य महारथाः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: They provide succour to those who seek refuge. They are roaming the world in disguise. Where are those maharathas now?

verse_data: कथं ते सूतपुत्रेण वध्यमानां प्रियां सतीम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Those powerful and infinitely energetic ones are suffering like eunuchs, while their beloved and chaste wife is tortured by the son of a suta.

verse_data: क्व नु तेषाममर्षश्च वीर्यं तेजश्च वर्तते
न परीप्सन्ति ये भार्यां वध्यमानां दुरात्मना

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Where is their intolerance? Where do their valour and energy flow? They cannot protect their wife from being tortured by an evil-minded one.

verse_data: मयात्र शक्यं किं कर्तुं विराटे धर्मदूषणम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: What can I possibly do with Virata, when dharma is being reviled? He witnesses an innocent one being tortured, but tolerates it.

verse_data: दस्यूनामिव धर्मस्ते न हि संसदि शोभते

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O king! You are not acting like a king in your treatment of Kichaka. Your dharma is that of a dasyu and is not deserving of an assembly hall.

verse_data: न कीचकः स्वधर्मस्थो न च मत्स्यः कथंचन

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I do not see any adherence to one's own dharma in Kichaka, or in Matsya. It seems to me that the courtiers are also oblivious of dharma.

verse_data: नाहमेतेन युक्ता वै हन्तुं मत्स्य तवान्तिके

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O King Virata! I will not censure you in this assembly of people. O Matsya! But it is not right that I should be tortured in your presence. The courtiers have witnessed that Kichaka is being treated as an exception."
Virata replied,
"I do not know anything about your quarrel, since that occurred outside my sight. Unless I know the truth, how can I judge skilfully?"
Vaishampayana said

verse_data: साधु साध्विति चाप्याहुः कीचकं च व्यगर्हयन्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Having learnt what had happened, those present in the assembly honoured Krishna a lot. They congratulated her and condemned Kichaka.
The courtiers said,

verse_data: परो लाभश्च तस्य स्यान्न स शोचेत्कदाचन

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "The man who possesses this long-eyed one with the unblemished limbs as a wife, has obtained the supreme and need not sorrow over anything."
Vaishampayana said
The courtiers saw Krishna and honoured her in this fashion. Because of anger, there were drops of perspiration on Yudhishthira's forehead.

verse_data: गच्छ सैरन्ध्रि मात्र स्थाः सुदेष्णाया निवेशनम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Kouravya spoke to the princess who was his beloved queen. "O Sairandhri! Do not stay here. Go to Sudeshna's abode.
The wives of brave ones suffer on account of their husbands. Though suffering, they conquer the worlds of their husbands through their servitude.

verse_data: मन्ये न कालं क्रोधस्य पश्यन्ति पतयस्तव

verse_translation.debroy_trans: I think that your husbands do not see this as a time for anger. Therefore, the gandharvas, who are like the sun in their energy, are not rushing to help you.

verse_data: गच्छ सैरन्ध्रि गन्धर्वाः करिष्यन्ति तव प्रियम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: O Sairandhri! You do not know that this is not the right time and are prancing around like a dancing girl. You are disturbing the Matsyas, who are gambling in the king's assembly hall. O Sairandhri! Depart and the gandharvas will act so as to bring you pleasure."
Droupadi replied,

verse_data: तस्य तस्येह ते वध्या येषां ज्येष्ठोऽक्षदेविता

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "I follow dharma for the sake of those who are extremely tolerant. If the eldest one is addicted to dice, anyone can oppress them."
Vaishampayana said
Having spoken these words, Krishna rushed to Sudeshna's residence. The one with the beautiful hips had her hair flowing freely and her eyes were red with anger.

verse_data: शुशुभे वदनं तस्या रुदन्त्या विरतं तदा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: When she stopped crying, her face was like the lunar disc in the sky, freed from a net of clouds.
Sudeshna asked,

verse_data: कस्याद्य न सुखं भद्रे केन ते विप्रियं कृतम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O one with the lovely hips! O beautiful one! Who has oppressed you and why are you crying? O fortunate one! Whose happiness will end today and who has acted towards you in an unpleasant way?"
Droupadi replied,

verse_data: सभायां पश्यतो राज्ञो यथैव विजने तथा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "Kichaka kicked me when I went to fetch liquor for you. The king looked on in the assembly hall, as if this had occurred in private."
Sudeshna replied,
"O one with the beautiful hair! If you so think, I will have Kichaka killed. He has been intoxicated by desire and has lusted for one who is not obtainable."
Droupadi said,

verse_data: अन्ये वै तं वधिष्यन्ति येषामागः करोति सः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "He has caused injury to others and they will kill him. I think it is certain that he will go today to the world beyond."
Vaishampayana said,
Having been kicked by the son of a suta, the beautiful princess Krishna blazed forth and planned the general's death. Drupada's daughter then went to her own residence

verse_data: कृत्वा शौचं यथान्यायं कृष्णा वै तनुमध्यमा
गात्राणि वाससी चैव प्रक्षाल्य सलिलेन सा

verse_translation.debroy_trans: and having purified herself, the slender-waisted Krishna washed her body and her garments with water.

verse_data: किं करोमि क्व गच्छामि कथं कार्यं भवेन्मम

verse_translation.debroy_trans: Weeping, she thought about how she might emerge from her misery. "What will I do? Where will I go? How will my task be accomplished?"

verse_data: इत्येवं चिन्तयित्वा सा भीमं वै मनसागमत्
नान्यः कर्ता ऋते भीमान्ममाद्य मनसः प्रियम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: While she was thinking in this way, Bhima surfaced in her mind. "Other than Bhima, no one can act so as to bring pleasure to my mind."

verse_data: तत उत्थाय रात्रौ सा विहाय शयनं स्वकम्

verse_translation.debroy_trans: She arose from her bed in the night. The spirited and chaste Krishna possessed a protector. Afflicted with great grief in her mind,

verse_data: सा वै महानसे प्राप्य भीमसेनं शुचिस्मिता

verse_translation.debroy_trans: the sweet-smiling Panchali swiftly went to Bhimasena in the kitchen, like a three-year old cow born in the forest approaches a bull, or a she-elephant approaches a large bull-elephant.
She was like a creeper embracing a large and flowering sala tree on the banks of the Gomati, like the wife of the king of animals waking up a sleeping lion in the deserted forest.
Unblemished Panchali spoke to Bhimasena in words that were as sweet as a veena uttering gandhara notes.

verse_data: उत्तिष्ठोत्तिष्ठ किं शेषे भीमसेन यथा मृतः

verse_translation.debroy_trans: "O Bhimasena! Arise! Arise! How can you sleep as if you are dead? He who lives after having embraced the wife of one not dead, is worse than a dead man.
How can you sleep tonight, not having done that deed, while that most sinful leader of my enemies lives?
Awoken by the princess, Kouravya arose from his bed and seated himself on a couch covered with cushions, looking like a monsoon cloud.
He asked his beloved queen, "Why have you come to me in this hurried fashion?

verse_data: न ते प्रकृतिमान्वर्णः कृशा पाण्डुश्च लक्ष्यसे
